_desc.NAICS_DESCRIPTION: Supermarkets and Other Grocery (except Convenience) Stores

_exec_summary.SummaryText:
Schnuck Markets Inc.
Perishable Warehouse
12921 Enterprise Way
Bridgeton, MO 63044

A.     Accidental release prevention and emergency policies.

The company recognizes it?s need to properly protect it?s employees, neighbors and environment. The safety and health of  all personnel  is important.  The control of accidents has been and will continue to be a basic responsibility  of all associates in the facility.

To establish safety in the plant , the company has installed a safety management program. This program is designed to achieve maximum efficiency and safety within the facility.

One component of the safety program has been the development  and implementation  of accidental release prevention and emergency response programs that comply with OSHA?s PSM  (Process Safety Management) CFR1910.119 and EPA?s RMP (Risk Management Program) 40 CFR Part 68. The facility manager is responsible for management of the accidental release and safety programs.

The purpose of this program is to prevent the occurrence, minimize the consequences, of significant releases of  Anhydrous ammonia( as used in a refrigeration process) This plan also has secondary purposes to effectively reduce the potential  for fire, explosion, minimize storm damage and other catastrophic events.  Overall these programs will prevent accidental  releases, injuries, and illnesses and avoid physical property damage.


B. Stationary source and substance used.

This  perishable facility is used for the  storage and distribution of refrigerated Produce, Dairy, and Meat products. This facility, for the purposes of refrigerating  the building, uses Anhydrous Ammonia ( cas # 7662-41-7)  as a refrigeration medium. This is a closed system and is not used  for process manufacturing. The total  charge for this system  is 17, 331 pounds.  Since  a remote possibility exists that  ammonia releases could occur, this system is regulated under OSHA PSM and EPA?S  RMP standard under program 3.

The refrigeration system cons

ists of   (4) four piston type compressors and two (2) screw compressors, ranging in horsepower from 125HP to 200 Hp each.  These compressors supply refrigerant to the appropriate evaporator units located throughout the facility. Within the engine room of the facility  three storage vessels are used for  high temperature accumulation, Low temperature accumulation and  a receiver tank which accept the return flow from the  system. Condensing units on the roof  remove the heat  from the refrigerant  and return it to the receiver.

C.     Summary of Worst  Case and Alternate Case scenarios

The worst case scenario is a release of pressurized Anhydrous Ammonia from the high pressure receiver, located in the engine room.
This release scenario is calculated to release 2988  pounds of liquid and vapor  over a ten (10) minute period. This scenario is based upon the unlikely  failure of the receiver vessel. The vessels total capacity is  5800 pounds, however, administrative controls are in place in the operation procedures to limit the vessel capacity to (50%)  fifty percent of total. Under worst case weather situations, and the vessel being located within the facility walls the ammonia vapor cloud could travel .99 miles before dispersing enough to no longer pose a threat or hazard to the public.

The worst case scenario is highly unlikely for the following reasons
1.     Epa?s RMP off-site consequence analysis data was used, and is considered to be very conservative 
2.     Industry standard were followed in the design and construction of the facility
3.     Pressure safety  valves are operational and in place on all vessels.
4.     Facility maintains it?s equipment  according to manufactures  specifications.
5.     Training programs are in place to insure operation of and response to emergencies are handled properly.


The alternative release scenario is designed around the release of  1325 pounds  of high pressure liquid ammonia from a ruptured  ? ? steel line. It is estimated that it woul

d take approximately five (5)  minutes to locate and close a stop valve to close the leak. Under alternative release scenarios (wind speeds at 3 meters per sec. And atmospheric conditions of ?D? or  partly cloudy, the affected area  is .31 miles.  After this distance the treat of the release diminishes to levels that are not hazardous to the public.

Releases of this nature are also unlikely for the following reasons:

1.     The liquid lines  are installed  to eliminate and or greatly reduce exposure to damage or accident.
2.     Pipe conditions are inspected  per PSM guidlines.
3.     Hazard  analysis? have been performed to locate and potentially eliminate  exposure hazards.
4.     There is a training program in place that trains all associates in the safe operation of equipment in this facility.
5.     Emergency response  plans are in place to  respond quickly to any release and eliminate the threat by closing isolation valves in the affected lines.


D.     Description of the accidental release program. (PSM)

The Program consists of the following elements:

<  Employee Participation: This program involves the employees in establishing the presence of and location of all existing ammonia in the facility. The program also ensures that all employees have access to the complete program.

<  Process Safety Information: Written information has been collected which enables the associate to identify and understand potential dangers to the system. This information consists of ammonia MSDS and a description  of the ammonia system.  

<  Process Hazard Analysis:  Formal studies using the ?what -if?? technique have been completed to look at any possible hazards in the system

<  Operating procedures: Written detailed procedures have been developed which describe the steps which should be followed to safely operate the ammonia system.

< Training: A training program has been implemented that include the use of video , written study materials, and work training  that allows associates  the

ability to work safely and with knowledge of the system characteristics and design.

<  Contractors: All contractors who are authorized to perform maintenance on this facility are screened for proper work habits, knowledge, and safe work  habits. Contractors are periodically evaluated to assure a safe work environment.

<  Pre-Start up Safety Review:  A pre start up review is conducted for all new projects to assure all safety programs are in place, training is completed, construction was  completed to design standards, prior  to putting the equipment in operation

<   Mechanical Integrity: This program ensure that  the ammonia systems are built and maintained to prevent mechanical or structural failures. The purpose of this program is to periodically inspect all mechanical and control systems to assure safe operation and integrity.

<  Hot Work Permit:  Hot work is handled according to Factory Mutual Insurance accepted practices.

<  Management of Change: The procedures are designed to  ensure that all changes to the operation system are properly reviewed.

<  Incident Investigation:  In the event of a incident(near miss)  the event is examined to see if any procedures or changes to plant design can be made to eliminate possible exposure in the future.  These  investigations are performed by an assigned investigation team  with the Safety Manager as  team leader.

<  Compliance Audits:  These are procedures to conduct regular audits of the program to ensure that the program is working  and is in place.


E.     Five Year Accident History

   No ammonia related accidents were identified for this facility in the previous five years which have resulted insignificant on or off site consequences.
